title.narrative: Skilling in Agripreneurship for increased Youth Employment - SAY Project

description.narrative:
AVSI is implementing a 4 Years project – Till end of 2024 funded by the Embassy of the Kingdom of Netherlands titled “Skilling in Agripreneurship for increased Youth Employment” – SAY project.
The project will contribute to: Embassy of the Kingdom of the Netherlands 2019-2024 Multi Year Strategic Plan, Vision 2040 of Uganda, Uganda National Agriculture Policy 2013 and the BTVET 10-year Strategic Plan for Revolutionizing Skills Development in Uganda (Skilling Uganda Initiative) with a focus on youth. It will furthermore contribute to the following Sustainable Development Goals: #1 No Poverty, #2 Zero Hunger, #5 Gender Equality, #7 Affordable and Clean Energy, #8 Decent Work and Economic Growth, #13 Climate Action, #15 Life On Land, #16 Peace, Justice, and Strong Institutions, #17 Partnerships for the Goals and will have a tangible impact to Uganda’s SDG report card.

The SAY Goal is: To contribute to increased agri-skills level and gainful employment of youth in the agriculture sector in Uganda The specific objectives are as follows: Specific Objective 1: Employable agribusiness skills levels of 10,000 youth 18-30 years old in target areas in Uganda enhanced by 2024. Specific Objective 2: Skilled youth (aged 18-30 years) employment in well-paying agribusiness jobs and self-run agripreneurship in target project areas of Uganda boosted by the end of the project (2024) Specific Objective 3: Youth aged 13 <18 years in target project areas of Uganda increased their engagement in agriculture for long-term career path or key economic venture by the end of project (2024) Specific Objective 4: Enabling environment for market-responsive agri-skilling and youth gainful engagement in agribusiness in Uganda strengthened by 2024
Youth aged 13<18 years for skills acquisition Sub-groups: 1.Students in secondary schools 2.Youth in justice system rehabilitation centers

Youth aged 18-30 years of age for immediate employment. Sub-groups: 1.Graduates of the SKY project lined up for upgrading to higher occupational level 2.Graduates from other institutions (unemployed or underemployed) 3.Finalists in universities and BTVET Institutions 4.Non-SKY supported youth Agripreneurs from communities

participating-org.narrative: Institute for International Cooperation and Development
Luigi Giussani Institute of Higher Education
Ministry of Education and Sports (Skilling Uganda Secretariat)

name.narrative: Districts of implementation: Kampala, Wakiso, Mukono, Mityana, Lira, Oyam, Gulu, Lamwo, Mbale, Kamuli, Soroti, Iganga, Kapchorwa, Mbarara, Kabale, Bushenyi Ibanda

sector.narrative: Dutch Government support to Uganda's Development Agenda through youth empower using agriskilling

description.narrative: Expenditure of the SAY project between November 2021 and end of March 2022. This includes funds transferred to partners for activities, procurement and running costs.
Expenditure on project activities including procurement, salaries and execution of preliminary activities such as contextual analysis studies, partners scouting and identification.

provider-org.narrative: Embassy of the Kingdom of the Netherlands

description.narrative: First Installment from EKN to AVSI to kickstart the project.
Funds transferred to AVSI by EKN for implementation of the project in 2022

The indicated expenditure is the sum total of funds spent within AVSI and disbursed to engaged partners to be utilized for the implementation of project activities planned to commence in the second quarter of 2021

title.narrative: This is the financial report for the first year of the project

description.narrative: Includes funds received from EKN, disbursement to partners, accountability from implementing partners and cost-share by the partners

title.narrative: The Narrative Technical Report for the period 1/11/2020 - 31/12/2021

description.narrative: The Report documents the implementation of the SAY project in its first year showing targets, results attained, challenges faced, recommendations to the challenges and opportunities that arose, lessons learnt and way forward.

title.narrative: OP 4.1.1: Government of Uganda institutions facilitated to operationalize agri-skilling and job creation systemic and policy reforms interventions

description.narrative: Among the mandates of the ASSC are profiling agricultural occupation for formalization, reviewing skills training delivery, establishing agriculture labour market information system, developing standards for skilling and employment in agriculture sector and supporting skills development as a whole. These are the components of their mandate that the SAY project plans to facilitate as contribution to the creation of enabling environment for youth engagement in agriculture. Attaining this output will increase the extent to which government bodies are playing their enabling environment creation role.

title.narrative: OP Ind 4.1.1a: # of Government of Uganda institutions facilitated to operationalize systemic and reform policies

comment.narrative: There are reform processes in line with job creation and agri-skilling which have been proposed under the Skilling Uganda Initiative, TVET Policy of 2019 and the National Strategy for Youth Employment in Agriculture (NSYEA).

In 2021, the SAY project targeted to collaborate with the Ministries of Agriculture Animal Industry and Fisheries, Ministry of Gender Labour and Social Development, and the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) to popularize the NSYEA and earn the buy in of the private sector actors to engage in agri-skilling and creation of jobs in the agriculture sector. The project also targeted engaging the Directorate of Industrial Training (DIT) of the Ministry of Education and Sports for reforms in assessment and certification to make it more responsive to the circumstances on the ground.

In 2021, after the joint regional awareness creation and popularization drives of the NSYEA conducted by AVSI, FAO, MAAIF and MGLSD, the role of private sector actors in the implementation of NSYEA was included in the policy document and implementation framework and forwarded to the National Planning Authority for endorsement and confirmation.
The DIT was able to agree on proposed reformed to have industrial actors nominate assessors for occupations for which DIT doesn't have pre-selected assessors. This reform has eased the assessment waiting time for youth after completion of training.

title.narrative: OP Ind 4.1.1a: # of Government of Uganda agri-skilling and job creation systemic and policy reforms interventions implemented
OP 2.1.1: Youth started and run their own agribusinesses as full time employment

description.narrative: Capacitating youth agribusinesses into strong commercial businesses which create value to the products produced in a sustainable manner, supporting the inclusion of youth in lucrative value chains, connecting youth and facilitating their active participation in modern agricultural markets, and facilitating linkages to financing mechanisms will result into OR 2.1.1. The project will develop capacities of youth in entrepreneurship, business planning and management to start and operate sustainable viable agribusinesses. The project will as well broker the development of stable and equal commercial relations throughout the whole chain. These relations will lead to a better integration of youth within the different links of the chain in order to satisfy market demands and market opportunities induced by modernization of agricultural chains and a more equal distribution of benefits and risks between the different chain actors. The project will also support youth engagement in forward integration through supporting access to business incubation services so that they add value to products and sell them further down the chains, domestically, regionally and internationally. The market chain development model that the project will promote makes use of identifying markets and zooming into specific buyers. Identified demand will be linked to production areas after which joint market chains will be established. The SAY project will play an important role in the identification of these potential buyers/markets and support more inclusive procurement strategies and practices in order to give youth the possibility to participate in highly modern markets as a trigger to become highly competitive businesses in national/ regional markets. These linkages will result in direct market access to domestic, regional and international export markets by youth. Also, through multi stakeholder processes, the project will influence chain actors in the targeted chains to share a common vision and objectives on fair trade, create synergies and develop sustainable products with youth. Additionally, it will endeavor to identify and interest key support institutions such as agri-finance and credit institutions to provide services to the youth businesses. The project will also design booster packages as well as set up challenge funds to provide alternative financing mechanisms. The project will employ a mix of market systems development approaches, all geared towards creating a demand pull from the consumers. Under this project, particular emphasis will be given to Making Market Work for the Poor (M4P) and Value Chain Development (VCD).

title.narrative: OP Ind 2.1.1b: # of agripreneurs supported with business booster packages (agribusiness challenge fund)

comment.narrative: The Challenge fund is set for the second and third year of the project so at baseline the number of recipients is 0

title.narrative: OP Ind 2.1.1a: # of self-employed youth

description.narrative: This is the count of youth who have gone into self employment have their skilling cycle

comment.narrative: The actual baseline will be determined after enrollment of the first cohort and will be adjusted annually until enrolment number of 10,000 is achieved

In 2021, 213 (94 females, 119 males) youth were able to either start or remain in self-employment after completion of their skilling cycle. 5 were winners of the SKY project's agribusiness challenge fund that was conducted as a pilot in Western Region.

title.narrative: Output (OP)1.1.1: Youth attended training in technical and soft agribusiness skills

description.narrative: For youth to get into either self-employment or wage employment they need to have sets of skills to be able to execute the given task. Under this project hands on technical and soft skills will be provided to the youth to enable them to compete favorably in the market. The technical skills in selected occupations will be provided by competent instructors who will use the reviewed and developed Assessment and Training Packages (ATPs) at level 2 and 3. The project will integrate soft and job readiness skills like ICT, communication, financial literacy, business planning, negotiation, work ethics, marketing, report writing critical thinking, problem solving among others into the training curriculum to enable them make meaningful contribution to their employers and businesses. The capacity of skills providers/instructors will be built through trainings and exposures to enable them provide up to date skills to the youth. The project will use mixed approaches to provide competent based skills to the youth. In the project youth will be trained onsite, off site and online. There will be a number of exposures visits to successful youth established farms and platforms for knowledge and information sharing as well as networking and linkages. Exceptional youth will be supported in national competition for competitive funding. In addition, for continuous and sustained learning, the project will support the establishment and functionality of BTVET/University business incubation hubs. An alumni association for the incubation hub will be formed to facilitate experience sharing and learning.

title.narrative: OP Ind 1.1.1b: # of youth (segregated by sex) completed the skilling cycle

description.narrative: This indicator capture the number of youth who have completed their training cycles having attended at least 90% of the planned sessions and is deemed ready for assessment and certification of their competencies.

comment.narrative: At the start of the project there were no youth who had completed any planned skilling processes under SAY project thus the baseline of 0.

A target of 200 out of 500 enrolled was set for completion level for the quarter because of the fact that the average skilling cycle is 4 months with a range of 1 month to 9 months of skilling duration. The 200 targeted was arrived at as in the hope that at least 220 youth will be enrolled for courses that take 3 months and below.

In Q4 of 2021, the target for completion was set to reflect the anticipated level of enrolment and the potential of at least 40% of the skilling cycles to spill into 2022. A target of 1000 completion number was then set.
A total number of 413 (176F/ 237M) youth completed the skilling cycle within the quarter a percentage of 55.6% of the total number youth who were enrolled.

Over 96% of the completion target for Q4 of 2021 was met with 967 (446 females, 521 males) completing the skilling cycles. Nevertheless, the overall completion target of 2021 of 2880 was not met by a wide margin due to low enrolment levels.

In the first quarter of 2022, a total of 679 enrolled youth completed their skilling in various agricultural occupations. This is below the target of the quarter of 1620. The reason behind is that skilling centers have had to adjust their skilling cycles to accommodate Life Skills and Entrepreneurship trainings. Additionally, youth enrolled in agri-institutions have had their cycles synchronized with the school calendar meaning they will complete their first cycle of 2022 in May. This will account for 60% of completion target for Q1.

title.narrative: OP Indicator 1.1.1a: # of youth enrolled for skilling

description.narrative: This indicator captures all the youth that have formally been enrolled into the SAY project to be skilled for specified agri-occupations

comment.narrative: The baseline is 0 because no youth has been enrolled at the onset of the project.
The 4th quarter of 2021 was lined up to absorb as much as possible the balance of the enrolment for 2021. A target of 2,000 beneficiaries was set for enrolment .

91.6% of the enrolment target for Q4 of 2021 was achieved as 1,833 (1005 females, 828 males) were enrolled by the skills providers. The balance of -172 from the quota and an overall deficit in enrolment of -662 have been carried into 2022 with partners granted no-cost extensions to ensure they complete their 2021 targets.

In the 3rd quarter of 2021, the enrollment of youth 18-30 years of age was 498 (296Male, 59.4%; 202 Female, 40.6%). The target for the quarter was 500 youth. this means the project almost met the target of the quarter but had an enrolment balance of 256 youth to cover from Quarter 2. The enrolment level in females is almost 10% less than the 50% target. The project is dialoguing with communities in the targeted areas to ensure that females beneficiaries enroll into the project

The result for Q1 of 2022 is beyond the target of 1800 because of enrolment balance from 2021. Partners who have balances have been able to cover the enrolment balance. This means the enrolment rate is favourable going forward.
The second quarter of 2021 is the targeted as the first skilling period and a target number of 500 youth (250 females and 250 males) have been assigned for the engaged partners.

While the country (Uganda) is still dealing with the Coronavirus pandemic, the project has been able to engage partners who have agreed to enrol and skill a limited number of youth who will allow for the observation of the Standard Operations Procedures (SOPs) laid down by the Ugandan Ministry of Health to prevent the spread of the COVID19 virus. Therefore only about half (244 beneficiaries) the targeted enrollment was achieved in the quarter due to the above mentioned reasons. The enrollment was for the occupations of Horticulture producer (104), Animal Nutritionists (81), Poultry Breeders (17), Poultry Producers (10), Apiculturists (32).

title.narrative: SO2: Skilled youth (aged 18-30 years) employment in well-paying agribusiness jobs and self-run agripreneurship in target project areas of Uganda boosted by the end of the project (2024)

description.narrative: From the experience of SKY majority of the youth, at least 79% showed preference for self-employment. Even those engaged in waged employment had plans of engaging in agripreneurship. This has guided the strategy in the new project where more 70% of the youth will be skilled and facilitated to get into self-employment. For this reason, 2 pathways into employment will be executed, one for self-employment (agripreneurship) and the other for wage employment. Wage employment will be prioritized for youth with higher education level as they will have the competitive ability in the job market compared to those with lower educational levels. Self-employment will be open for all youth across the board. The first strategy will be to map all companies engaged in the lucrative upper nodes of the chain who are able to engage in skilling or integrating the skilled youth as part of their supply chain or as employees. For youth going into self-employment, their package will include skilling in entrepreneurship, soft skills and the technical aspects of the agripreneurship they are primed for, agribusiness incubation and development services including support from PUM experts, opportunity to compete for the agribusiness challenge fund grant, linking to a big actor in the value chain for off-take and access to investment capital, and business formalization support. A market-driven approach will be designed to address bottle-necks that hinder access to lucrative market opportunities by the youth. This category of youth will be introduced to value chains as contracted supply chain contributors or agents of big companies to disseminate agro-inputs/products and offer after-sales services. External markets in South Sudan, Rwanda and Kenya will be targeted for the self-employed youth. The youth skilled under SKY 1 will form the first cohort for upgrading/retooling in this category. Occupations at level 2 and 3 will be the priority entry point for youth targeted for wage employment (at agribusiness companies). The big agribusinesses engaged in the selected value chain enterprises will be mapped out and partnered with through the multi-stakeholder platforms to take in the final year youth from Universities and Colleges for internship/apprenticeship placement and retain a certain quota as their employees. Job Brokerage through the job connection platforms is another strategy that will be executed to get the youth into well-paying jobs. Occupational health and safety is another priority aspect that will be addressed for youth to be employed by companies. The project will conduct career awareness sessions for university/college finalist students to enable them understand how early-career jobs fit into a career trajectory and thus prepare for their first job experience. Work readiness skills training will be the main service package for wage employed youth and will be delivered in a phased manner with engagement of agribusiness staff and matching capacity needs of the youth. SKY staff will actively participate in the enrolment of the youth to ensure that only those with the desired attributes are enrolled into the project. This is a critical objective on which one of the key outcomes of the project that is of national importance (reduction of youth unemployment) directly hinges on. If the post-skilling support pays off this objective will be achieved to a magnitude dependent on IO 2.1.

title.narrative: SO Ind 2: % of employed youth graduates 18-30 years (segregated by sex and employment type) earn at least €120/month

description.narrative: This indicator will track the income and employment statuses of youth at least 6 months after completion of their skilling cycles

comment.narrative: This indicator is dependent on youth who have undergone and completed their skilling cycles. At baseline it is 0 because no youth has been skilled.

In 2021, a total of 333 out of 1071 (who completed their skilling cycles) entered employment. Of these, 190 who are earning at least UGX500,000 per month. This is broken down as 59 females and 131 males. 158 of those earning at least UGX5000,000 are self employed while 32 are waged employed. Measured as a portion of the total target of 14,400 youth expected to completed their skilling cycle by the end of the project, this year's number of 190 youth earning at least UGX500,000 per month is 1.32% of the project target and has fallen short of the 2021 targeted of 12%. The reasons for this are numerous and include late enrolment of beneficiaries due to lockdown, scarcity of employment opportunities and many youth in transition phase from training to work.

title.narrative: SO3: Youth aged 13 <18 years in target project areas of Uganda increased their engagement in agriculture for long-term career path or key economic venture by the end of project (2024)

description.narrative:
Getting the young people of school-going age to engage in agribusiness is key for the future of the agriculture sector. So the intervention in schools and remand homes is aiming at increasing the number of youth in agribusiness or agriculture occupations. by promoting agriculture as a viable career and income generation option among the youth 13<18 years. As a strategy for promoting positive mindset change among youth 13<18 years, the project will seek to expose youth to learning opportunities that demonstrate the wide range of opportunities within agribusiness to stimulate interest and innovation. This will be done by unpacking agriculture in such a way that demystifies the subject that has been relegated to an elective subject in the new curriculum and promote it as a subject of choice among the students. This will set a foundation for the future workforce in agribusiness as well as foster new agripreneurships Results from SKY indicated an increased number of students choosing agriculture and this is expected to further increase with the implementation of the new project.
The implementation in schools will be through the student agribusiness clubs building on the success of SKY and paying specific attention harmonizing interventions with the new curriculum with regard to assessment and certification. All skills attained by the students under the project intervention will be certified by DIT to ensure skills and competencies are built from early stages of the youth career in agribusiness. The main proposed programming strategies, models and approaches for this objective (SO3) will be: a) Hands-on knowledge and skills transfer: AVSI proposes to invest in practical session learning sites in targeted schools for the youth in schools to learn agricultural and entrepreneurial skills and appreciate their productive outcome when put into use. These learning sites run by highly trained facilitators will run as centers of excellence where by youth skilled by the project are deployed to facilitate clinics in different topics of interest for other youth from other schools or nearby communities. This will create a snowball effect that will engage more youth in agribusiness ventures, thus amplifying the project’s impact and increase youth engagement in agriculture. b) Promotion of youth-led Innovations: Youth will be supported under the new phase to engage in selected lucrative enterprises that present the best business opportunities. The new phase will be designed to involve the strong private sector players in skilling youth at agri-institutions to influence the delivery model of agri-institutions towards being market oriented. AVSI will engage with agri-institutions to allocate the finalists part of the infrastructure to facilitate learning with production model and facilitate finalist youths and the institutions to engage in business transactions. The youth will be able to generate capital for self-start up or linked to available opportunities for wage employment. c) Exposure and networking: Exposing the youth to the dimensions of agriculture and various nodes of the value chain so that they can see and appreciate the importance and value of agriculture to individual and community socio-economic transformation. When the young people see the amount of money that change hands along the value chains there is a high chance that they will be inspired and attracted. Introducing the young people to networks of value chain actors will be an inspirational and eye-opening opportunity for them to draw closer to agriculture and become protagonists too. d) Climate and environment compliant innovations: In the next phase, the project will focus on waste management. The project proposes to build the capacity of youth in agri-institutions to produce briquettes from food and farm wastes (Banana peels, coffee husks, maize, cassava paste, etc) and briqette saving stoves for domestic use, restaurants, schools and chicken brooders. The youth will produce honey comb briquettes that have a very high efficiency and produce a very good flame. The project will facilitate trained youth and women to start business in briquette making and develop outlets for briquettes and stoves in different parts of the country. the project will also support youth to design new stove/energy products for selected businesses such as chicken brooders for poultry farms. e) Partnership with Children Remand Homes and Rehabilitation Center: AVSI will sign MoUs with remand homes to impart employable agribusiness skills to youth during their time at the remand homes. An adapted Earn As You Learn model will be applied to ensure that the youth earn some income and acquire startup that will allow them have a beginning to integrate back into society.

title.narrative: SO Ind 3b: % of targeted youth 13<18 years engaged in agribusiness ventures after project intervention

description.narrative: This indicator tracks children's engagement in agriculture ventures while at school and at home.

comment.narrative: Baselines will be determined at enrolment

title.narrative: SO Ind 3a: % of targeted youth 13<18 years engaged in the agriculture field

comment.narrative: The baseline will be determined post-enrollment

In 2021, the target was to have 50% of the youth aged 13<18 years skilled in schools and remand home engage in agricultural ventures as part of the adoption and application of the knowledge and skills acquired through the SAY mindset change and skills development activities.

In 2021, the targeted secondary schools, like all other schools in Uganda, remained closed (without learning activities) as part of the measures to control the spread of the #COVID19 virus within the Ugandan population.
Skilling took place at Naguru Remand home were 155 juveniles (152 males and 3 females) underwent skilling along the horticulture, rabbitry and poultry value chains. Of the 155 youth who were skilled at the Naguru Remand Home, 46 were released and all indicate they are engaged in agricultural activities, which is 29.7% of the total. An additional 76 (49%) are engaged in horticulture while still at the Remand home. The overall total of skilled youth putting the acquired skills and knowledge into practice is 78.7%. about 30% above the 2021 target of 50%.

title.narrative: OP 3.1.2 Students executed self-driven innovative & climate smart agribusiness projects to improve their skills sets

description.narrative: In line with this the project will engage students in climate-smart agripreneurship and equip them with the essential knowledge to apply in entrepreneurial ventures in and out of the school context. Awareness creation activities will be conducted and students in the clubs will be supported to integrate climate smart actions into their activities. Schools will be engaged to support Climate-Smart initiatives by students including providing space for production using conservation agriculture. These initiatives will mostly be short term with the production cycle fitting into the school term so that students are able to go through the full cycle. The project team will evaluate each of these initiatives and support further learning. Implementation will also target to tap into the innovative capacity of students by providing them with an environment and opportunities for learning, inspiration, imagination and developing new ideas in climate smart action. Climate smart challenge competitions will be organized and students engaged to identify climate change challenges within their community and develop innovative solutions to address the challenges. High impact ideas will be supported to scale up and shared on platforms designed to connect youth in agribusiness for knowledge and experience sharing across the entire project.

title.narrative: OP Ind 3.1.2a: # of students who are engaged in climate smart ventures

description.narrative: This will be a quarterly reported indicator. Only new students engaging in CSA will be reported per quarter.

comment.narrative: Baseline will be determined at enrollment as some schools might already have students engaged in CSA

title.narrative: OP Ind 3.1.2b: # of school-based Agribusiness Clubs with Climate Change committee established

description.narrative: This is a one-off indicator. The schools are required to either form or continue with the agribusiness clubs

title.narrative: SO4: Enabling environment for market-responsive agri-skilling and youth gainful engagement in agribusiness in Uganda strengthened by 2024

description.narrative:
In order for youth skilled under the SAY project to gain access to lucrative employment opportunities or commodity markets, stakeholders/actors have facilitation roles to play and mechanisms to put in place and operationalize. In essence, the youth need an enabling environment for them to attain their full potential in agribusiness as employees or agripreneurs. An enabling environment combines macro-economic policies that favour markets and trade, the provision of inputs, related physical infrastructure (such as roads and irrigation) and social infrastructure (such as ‎‎education and research). Creating the desired enabling environment for youth engagement in agriculture requires leadership and the engagement of all key stakeholders given the complex challenges facing the sector around the world, especially in emerging markets like Uganda. The Agriculture Growth Enabling Index (AGEI) lists 4 main components of the enabling environment that must be prioritized for interventions especially in emerging economies like Uganda. These components are governance (policy frameworks, regulations and value chain power mandates), capital (human, financial and other resources), markets and agriculture factors (inputs, production systems, climate etc) . These components are well incorporated and prioritized in the Uganda Agriculture Policy 2013 and the National Development Plan III. Governments in any country are primary duty bearers who play pivotal roles in creating an enabling environment for agricultural development. By providing a stable policy environment and avoiding unpredictable policy shifts, poor regulatory transparency, weak contract enforcement or restrictive investment policies, farmers can be supported to productively and beneficially engage in trading activities. A supportive enabling environment depends not only on the presence of laws and regulation, but their implementation; in agriculture, this requires strong political support for the sector at the highest levels. The role of private sector in economic development is undoubtedly critical. This is because 90% of the labour force in low and middle income economies are employed by the private sector and the sector controls the lion share of key agricultural resources such as land, financial capital and markets. They SAY project proposes public-private partnerships in the agriculture ecosystem in Uganda to support efforts to bring about reforms in the enabling environment. This will be done through support to government bodies to implement policies reforms and plans focused on enhance the 4 components of AGEI. The project will also facilitate the participation of private sector actors in the reform interventions and advocate for their long-term commitment to contribute to the various processes aimed at improving employability of youth in the agriculture sector and creation of opportunities and mechanisms that will enhance the youth’s access to employment, investment capital, agricultural inputs and commodity markets. Achieving specific objective (SO) 4 will have a ripple effect on the other SOs as the outcome of SO4 is foundation on which the other outcomes of the project stand.
The strategy to achieve an improved enabling environment will include but not limited to: a) Enterprise support services: AVSI will map out all potential enterprise support organizations (ESOs) and provide this information to all the skilled youths for easy access to financial support. This AVSI will do through a designated private sector actor to establish formal collaboration with the identified partners. Under SKY, the Uganda Agribusiness Alliance (UAA) played this role and brought actors together and youths were able to benefit from the initiative. b) Collaboration with the public sector: AVSI recognizes that the public sector holds the mandate to carry out socio-economic development activities and that what development partners do is a contribution to this mandate. Having public institutions on board comes with several benefits that includes strategic and critical technical guidance, access to other opportunities, co-ownership of interventions and policy guidance. Under SKY project AVSI collaborated with Ministries of Education and Agriculture through their various Agencies and Departments. For the new project AVSI proposes to bring Ministry of Gender Labour and Social Development on board so that some inroads can be made into the labour market and create favourable enabling environment for youth to engage in agribusiness. c) Facilitation of ASSC: AVSI proposes to continue supporting the agriculture sector skills council by facilitating their activities and work plan. The ASSC still has pending activities in their 2016-2020 workplan that would not be fully implemented due to the disbandment of the Reform Taskforce and delay in operationalizing the TVET Council. d) Direct Engagement with Employers: A more formal collaboration between agri-institutions and employers/ private sector through MOUs will be up scaled in the next phase of the project. AVSI will map out all potential employers who can offer employer led skills and link them with the Agri-institutions for sustainable and long-term collaborations e) Participatory Learning: AVSI proposes to set a joint learning agenda between EKN, AVSI and targeted research institutions to increase the knowledge base on skills development and employment creation in the agriculture sector. The learning agenda will include action research that will be scientific and approved by the National Council of Science and Technology

title.narrative: SO Ind 4b: % of private sector-led initiatives that directly facilitated agri-skilling and job creation for youth in agriculture sector

description.narrative: This indicator will track efforts by private sector actors to take agri-skilling and job creation to the next level. One of those initiatives is the retention/employment of skilled youth as employees of the agribusinesses at which they have been skilled and those to whom the skills providers have recommended the youth for absorption into the work force.

comment.narrative: Private sector actors committed to retain an agreed quota of the youth they have skilled to become employers in their agribusinesses. This is a direct effort by private sector actors to create employment for youth within their own agribusiness.

As 2021 was marred with many restrictions of movements and clustering, limited interventions at sector level were planned. The only private sector-led initiative was the retention of skilled youth by agribusiness skills providers as their employees and recommending other skilled youth to other private sector employers for employment. This initiative was successfully implemented and led to the retention of 93 skilled youth (67 males and 26 females) retained by 10 agribusinesses. An additional 31 (22 males, 9 females) youth were engaged by other agribusinesses as employees thanks to the referral by the skills providers if SAY.

The job creation has been possible through business scale up technical assistance that SAY project has accorded the agribusinesses/skills providers that enabled them to increase their scale of operations which require hiring of additional staff who turned out to be the same beneficiary of the SAY project they skilled. More males 67 were retained as employees of agribusinesses than females (26) because at the centers where the most retention happened the number of female beneficiaries were low, so the male took the remaining available opportunities

title.narrative: SO Ind 4a: % of supported systemic and policy reforms that have led quality improvement in market-responsive agri-skilling

dimension.name: systemic reforms targeted by the SAY project for improvement in quality of agri-skilliing

comment.narrative: In 2021, the SAY project targeted 2 systemic reform process that would lead to quality improvements into market responsive agri-skilling. One of these was the adjustments in the assessment and certification calendar and assignment of assessors of competences of the skilled youth. AVSI successfully dialogued with Directorate of Industrial Training to have skills providers provide their own assessors in instances where DIT do not have qualified accessors for specific value chains and occupations. The proposed assessors by the skills providers had to undergo validation by DIT and orientation on the assessment process. The second systemic reform process targeted in 2021 was the involvement of the Directorate of Human Resources and Extension in the skilling of Extension Workers who would later be considered for absorption in the Government Extension system.

The DIT was able to adjust the assessment and certification calendar to monthly and allowed assessors proposed by skills providers to assess the competencies of skilled youth. This resulted in ensuring assessment was conducted on time at the end of the skilling cycle. Ministry of Agriculture activity participated in the training of extension workers (Plant Doctors) who were subsequently absorbed in the extension system of the government and are now waiting to be assigned budgetary votes in District budget after which they will start work in their respective localities as government extension workers.

title.narrative: IO 3.1: 5,000 youth aged 13 <18 years increased their agripreneurship practical knowledge and skills levels

description.narrative: In order to engage in agripreneurship or agricultural jobs, youth people need the required technical and soft skills. This will be realized after the skills and knowledge transfer in schools is executed and students have acquired the skills and knowledge. The Hands-on model knowledge and skills transfer will be used. Students will be facilitated to learn agriculture better by relating the core concepts of agriculture learnt in class with the practical context at the learning sites established by the project to allow for the application of new knowledge and skills in solving real-life challenges. The focus here will be on facilitating the students to apply agricultural and entrepreneurial knowledge that will enable them either to start their own agripreneurships back home or pursue agriculture at higher level.

title.narrative: IO Ind 3.1b: % of targeted youth 13<18 years who started own agripreneurship

description.narrative: Tracked annually through survey

comment.narrative: To be determined at enrollment

title.narrative: IO Ind 3.1a: % of targeted youth 13<18 years who scored at least 70% post-test score in agripreneurship assessment

description.narrative: This indicator is measured at the end of the skilling cycle, once a year

title.narrative: IO 4.2: Private Sector-led initiatives facilitated market responsive agri-skilling and job creation for youth in agriculture

description.narrative: One of the biggest output here is the establishment of internship and apprenticeship schemes that allows for placement of trainees at agribusinesses and through agree feedback processes training institutions are informed of the skills gaps in the trainees and areas of reforms in the training process. Additionally, absorption of skilled youth into the workforce of agribusinesses or value chains as key actors is another anticipated output. The Job Centers will be an important structure to host and coordinate mechanisms put in place. Bringing together private and public sector actors to common platforms with the aim of driving forward the skilling agenda will go a long way to bring forth solutions on issues affecting employment of youth in agribusiness and participation of the private sector in imparting the demanded skills to the youth. This will build on what SKY project had initiated and was starting to pay off.

title.narrative: IO Ind 4.2: % of private sector-led initiatives that facilitated youth to access market-responsive agri-skilling and job opportunities in the agriculture sector
OP 4.2.1: Youth trainees accessed internship and apprenticeship placements through established schemes

description.narrative: One of the documented barriers to graduates from colleges and universities in Uganda is their lack of job readiness and mismatch of skills between what is required for the jobs and what they possess. There are huge gaps in both technical and soft skills of most graduates due to limited exposure to work environment and hands-on practicals. In order to address this, the project intends to facilitate youth trainees from University and colleges particularly targeting finalists to access and secure on job training placements as a way of enhancing their employability skills and knowledge. This will be achieved through facilitating establishment of the private sector-led internships schemes for youth trainees. Identifying and profiling partners with the potential to provide internship and apprenticeship which will be followed by signing of formal partnership agreements with institutions.

title.narrative: OP Indicator 4.2.1a: # of youth trainees who accessed internship with agribusinesses

comment.narrative: This target is set with the hope that agri-institutions will reopen in 2021 and there will be students requiring internship placements and apprenticeships
Educational institutions remained closed through out 2021, so no internship and apprenticeship placements took place

title.narrative: OP Indicator 4.2.1b: # of youth trainees who accessed apprenticeship placements with agribusinesses
OP Indicator 4.2.1c: # of private sector-led internship/apprenticeship schemes established
Studies and surveys conducted to establish benchmarks and measure achievement of results

description.narrative: Over the 4 year period of the project studies will be conducted at start, during and at the end of the project cycle to set benchmarks and determine baselines and to measure progress on key performance indicators (KPIs) at output and outcome levels. These studies include 1 - Contextual Analysis/Baseline Survey 2- Annual KPI Survey 3- Midterm Evaluation 4 - Final Evaluation 5 - Tracer Study

title.narrative: Final evaluation conducted

description.narrative: At the end of the implementation period of the project, a donor sanctioned consultant will conduct the final evaluation of the project following OECD standards and protocols

title.narrative: Midterm Evaluation conducted and report submitted to EKN

description.narrative: At the halfway point of the project, a consultant will be engaged to evaluation the project progress in terms of relevance, efficiency, effectiveness and sustainability of interventions. This evaluation will be conducted by an external consultant sanctioned by the donor

title.narrative: Annual KPI survey conducted

description.narrative: In the 4th quarter of every programming year, the project will conduct a survey to determine the progress of achievement of annual targets for each KPI

comment.narrative: The KPI survey was planned for December 2021 spilling into January 2022 inorder to capture results covering period ending 31st December 2021. The survey focused on Specific objectives 1, 2 and 3 which are outcome results for skills development for youth 18-30 years, employment of youth 18-30 years in self-run or group-based agripreneurships and empowerment of youth 13<18 years to engagement in agriculture respectively.

The Key Performance Indicator (KPI) Survey ran from December 2021 to end of January 2021. For SO1, progress on skills development of enrolled youth was assessed using skilling records available at the skilling centers. This was done successfully across all the regions covering 30 skilling centers. Indicators of focus: OP Indicator 1.1.1a: # of youth (Y) (segregated by sex) enrolled for skilling OP Ind 1.1.1b: # of youth (segregated by sex) completed the skilling cycle OP Ind 1.1.2a: # of youth (segregated by sex) assessed by DIT OP Ind 1.1.2b: # of youth (segregated by sex) that passed DIT assessments and certified OP Ind 1.1.3: # of refugee youth trained in financial literacy For SO2, partners provided details of youth who had completed skilling and hard entered employment. The Survey team then tracked them using the captured biodata that included GPS location and were able to meet the youth and validate if they were employed or not. For those who were found to be employed, data including duration in employment, employment type, earnings and other aspects were captured. For those in self-run agripreneurships, data on startup capital, monthly and seasonal income, business development services accessed and prevailing gaps were captured. Indicators of focus: OP Ind 2.1.1a: # of self-employed youth (segregated by sex) OP Ind 2.1.1b: # of agripreneurs (AGP) (segregated by sex) supported with business booster packages (agribusiness challenge fund) OP Ind 2.1.2: # of refugee youth who accessed financial credit through VSLAs OP Ind 2.1.3a: # of skilled youth 18-30 years (segregated by sex) who applied at least 1 CSA approach in their agribusiness ventures OP Ind 2.1.3b: # of skills providers who applied at least 1 CSA approach in their agribusiness ventures OP Ind 2.2.1a: # of skilled youth (segregated by sex) wage employed OP Ind 2.2.1.b: # of skilled youth graduates retained by agribusinesses OP Ind 2.2.1c: # of agribusinesses that absorbed skilled youth graduates (segregated by sex)
For SO3, the focus was on Naguru Remand home where 155 Juvenile underwent skilling in 2021. The survey captured they progress of skilling with attention to completion rate and application of acquired knowledge and skills into practice. Indicators of focus: OP Ind 3.1.1a: # of youth (segregated by sex) who attended capacity development activities (S4A, Life skills training) OP Ind 3.1.1b: # of youth (segregated by sex) who attained at least 70% post-test score in agripreneurship assessment OP Ind 3.2.1a: # of youth in rehabilitation centers trained in agripreneurship skills These were the 3 dimensions of the KPI survey.

title.narrative: Tracer Study conducted

description.narrative: Starting at the end of the second year, the project will conduct tracing of project beneficiaries to assess their progress, identify skills gaps and challenges in their occupations and ventures and conduct remedial follow-ups

title.narrative: Contextual Analysis/Baseline Survey conducted

comment.narrative:
AVSI conducted a contextual analysis survey internally as part of the roll-out process of the project and most importantly to enable the establishment of benchmarks against which to measure progress, determine baselines for some population level/systemic key performance indicators and to assess/identify potential partners and collaborators to engage in the project. The CAS sampled 393 youth aged 18-30 years, 144 youth aged 13<18 years (116 in schools and 28 in rehabilitation centers), 21 employers, 26 skills providers, 10 secondary schools, 5 line Ministries/Departments/Agencies, 4 private sector enablers, 4 CSOs and 1 donor agency. With 98% response rate and findings computed at a confidence level of 95% for quantitative data and attainment of response saturation by the 20th respondent for qualitative data, the results of the CAS is generalizable for the variables covered.
Engagement in skills training:  38% of youth 18-30 years are currently or in the past 1 year pursued studies, skills training or apprenticeship  69% of the students 13<18 years are studying agriculture as an examinable subject while 31% are not. More male students study agriculture 93% compared to 59% of females.  For children in conflict with the law, 82% were engaged in some form of agriculture before admission to the rehabilitation programme  The 26 skills providers’ survey are engaged in skilling covering various occupations in the 4 sub-sectors of agriculture and at different occupation levels. Most of the skills providers offer skilling at levels 1 (78%) and 2 (81%) mainly with only 41% covering level 3 and 30% in level 4 occupation skilling.  All the 10 surveyed schools have school farm/production units in which livestock, crops and agroforestry production and value addition processes take place.  All the schools except Gayaza High School (does not have Agriculture at A level) offer Agriculture as an examinable subject at both Ordinary and Advanced levels and current student enrolment for the subject
Skills Training Delivery:  The skilling centres mainly use 4 skills delivery methods with all of them conducting practical hands-on sessions; 70% using coaching, mentorship and job shadowing; 74% using the instructor-led classroom model and 11% conduct online sessions. Hands-on practical session is the predominant skilling model across all the nodes of the agriculture value chains followed by instructor-led classroom sessions, coaching/mentorship/job-shadowing, and online sessions  Secondary schools use 3 main models for agriculture training namely practical in school farms/production units, classroom theory and learning visits at a rate of at least 80% for each providing very suitable all-round training for the students
Duration of skilling cycles:  The trainings/skilling cycles were found to be 4.48 months long on average. The longest at 12 months for the Agriculturalists trained at Agricultural Colleges and the shortest at 1 months for some occupations skilled for by Agribusinesses
Skilling Costs:  The average costs for (excluding DIT assessment fees) was found to be UGX720,591/-. The skilling cost for each youth ranged from UGX120,000/- for a month-long non-residential training in food processing to UGX2,500,000/- for level 3 training in Dairy Value Addition.
Assessment and Certification by DIT:  16% (19% female, 13% male) were found to have been assessed and 97% passed by the DIT. All were old former beneficiaries of the SKY project.
Demand/Interest in Agripreneurship among the youth  97% of the youth (with insignificant variation between male and female preferences) indicated that they are interested in acquiring the skills and knowledge in agripreneurship  89% indicated interest in technical skills compared to 44% that registered interests in soft skills  The youth in rehabilitation were found to be interested in entrepreneurship skills (43%), practical agronomic skills (36%), life skills (25%), and future skills such as in IT (14%) that they will use when they are discharged.
Involvement in Agripreneurship:  Youth 18-30 years, 75% (78% females, 73% males) were engaged in agriculture in various value chains and levels with 72% engaged in crops, 48% in livestock and 2% each in agroforestry and aquaculture.  82% of youth in rehabilitation centres were engaged in agriculture before admission.  For youth 13<18 years in schools, 79% (81% female, 74% male) were stated that they were currently engaged in agriculture ventures either at home, at school 13<18 years’ youth earnings from agripreneurship  Youth undergoing rehabilitation at Naguru Remand Home who indicated that they were engaged in agriculture earned an average of UGX 776,111/- per year  For the youth in secondary schools, their earning from engagement in agriculture averaged UGX771,019/= per years from the ventures
Youth employment (18-30 years category):  45% employed. More females (53%) were in employment compared to males (41%).  Wage employment accounts for 54% (47% female, 61% male) of the employment the youth are engaged in while 46% (53% female, 41% male) are self-employed  23% (25% female, 22% male) are formally employed while 53% (43% female, 63% male) are in informal employment. Those who work for family ventures account for 25% (33% female, 17% male) of youth who were found to be employed.
Income for youth 18-30 years:  59% mainly earn income at a monthly and seasonal frequency. At weekly and daily frequency are 19% and 15% respectively. 19% of the youth indicated that they were not earning any money.  Monthly: 356,391/- (251,009 female, 462,325 male) from all sources  Monthly: 255,897/- (236,860 female, 274,477male) from agriculture  The self-employed youth earn more (UGX329,689/-) than their wage employed counterparts (UGX260,945/-).
Ownership of assets:  The current average value of the assets owned by the youth is UGX12,442,114/- (UGX8,049,870/- female; UGX16,262,842/- male) with value of assets owned by male youth double that of females.  Most of the assets are acquired through purchase (86%) and family inheritance (25%). Only a small fraction is acquired through donations (5%), bank loans (2%) and support from projects (1%).
Engagement in community groups:  70% of the youth are engaged in at least one community group. More female (75%) than male (65%) are members of community groups.
Legal status of agribusinesses:  14% of agripreneurship ventures are formally registered. The 86% unregistered ones are because of fear of taxes, lack of information on registration, misinformation about the implications of registration, and lack of funds to meet the registration requirements.
Financial linkages:  32% (28% female, 37% male) owned bank accounts  Female youth (41%) preferred microfinance institutions than commercial banks while at least 46% of male youth go for commercial banks compared to 28% for microfinance institutions.  Youth currently have an average account balance of UGX401,098/= (UGX191,887/- female, UGX561,797/- male) with financial institutions  13% (8 females, 9 males) of the youth borrow from financial institutions in last 2 years with males taking UGX8,211,111/- and females UGX4,087,500/-

title.narrative: OP 1.1.3: Refugee youth acquired agripreneurship and financial literacy knowledge and skills

description.narrative: Refugees and host communities in community groups will receive financial literacy training as part of financial inclusion package to enable them access financial capital for agribusiness investment.

title.narrative: OP Ind 1.1.3: # of refugee youth trained in financial literacy

description.narrative: This indicator is a count of the refugee and host community group members enrolled into the project and trained by the project in financial literacy.

comment.narrative: In 2022, a total of 3,200 beneficiaries in the refugee context will be targeted with financial literacy training.

391 beneficiaries were trained in financial literacy in the first quarter of 2022. More trainings are planned for following quarters and their is optimism that the target will be achieved by end of Q3
It was not possible to conduct financial literacy training in refugee contexts in 2021. The training was moved to 2022

title.narrative: OP 4.1.2: Skilled youth linked to government programs/integrated into agriculture extension labour force

description.narrative: The Government of Uganda is currently implementing development programs in the agriculture where skilled labour is required and investment resources are available under certain conditions to youth such as agripreneurs. Engaging the directorate of human resources at MAAIF for integration of youth skilled as Plant doctors, artificial insemination technicians and farm managers into extension system will facilitate the youth’s access to waged employment. The project has also earmarked Ministry of Gender Labour and Social Development for a double-pivot role; to link skilled youth to the various youth empowerment schemes and support the establishment of job connection platforms, a key enabler to access to market information and other opportunities

title.narrative: OP Ind 4.1.2b: # of youth absorbed into the Government agriculture extension system

comment.narrative: The project targeted to have youth trained as Plant Doctors and Artificial Insemination technicians to be absorbed into the national extension service by MAAIF

MAAIF absorbed all the 42 Plant Doctors trained at IBO Mixed Farm in Mbarara. These were allocation to the Production Departments of the Districts of their origin for deployment as extension workers with full inclusion into the payroll starting 1st July 2021. Prior to that they will receive stipends for every engagement they are assigned to.

title.narrative: OP Ind 4.1.2a: # of youth linked to government programs/initiatives
Specific Objective (SO)1: Employable agribusiness skills levels of 10,000 youth 18-30 years old in target areas in Uganda enhanced by 2024

description.narrative: The SAY project provides the opportunity to skill 10,000 more youth and place them on the paths of sustainable wage employment or agripreneurships. The focus in the new project is to skills youth (previously skilled at level 1 under SKY and new entrants) in higher occupational levels with both technical and soft skills so that they are all round and so that they are able to get employed in higher positions that also attract more pay. Achievement of this objective (SO1) will go a long way to contribute to an improved quality of the agriculture workforce in Uganda and open doors for the skilled youth.

title.narrative: SO Indicator 1: % of skilled youth 18-30 years with certified job competencies that are in high demand for agribusiness occupations

comment.narrative: This indicator starts its baseline as 0 because it's dependent on youth trained by the project.

Out of the 14,400 skilled youth targeted for assessment and certification of competencies, 2,400 were targeted for assessment and certification, which is 16.5% of project life target. 2021 achievement was 3.25%, which is below the year's target. this is because the implementation period in which assessment and certification was possible was severely due to the prolonged lockdown that was imposed in the country to combat the spread of COVID19 virus. In this period, DIT suspended Assessments. Nevertheless, the project team has made contingency plans to have the pending assessments conducted in the first quarter of 2022.

title.narrative: OP 2.2.1: Skilled youth hired by agribusinesses for wage employment

description.narrative: The above output results from how self-employed and waged employed youth performs in their jobs determines if they excelled or not. To facilitate skilled youth to ‘stand out of the crowd’ and enable their quick and smooth transition into employment, their capacities will be enhanced through the job center. The job center is a one-stop point where youth seeking support to prepare themselves to enter the labor force, looking for employment opportunities and looking to improve their employability are served. The Center is a free, walk-in job search assistance service point helping job-seekers create resumes, prepare for interviews, and provides access to community resources and information. The job center also provides access to a computer lab, computer tutorials, skills assessments, and internet job-search services designed to improve job-seeking skills and help young people and women get jobs. The above output results from how self-employed and waged employed youth perform in their jobs determines if they excelled or not. To facilitate skilled youth to ‘stand out of the crowd’ and enable their quick and smooth transition into employment, their capacities will be enhanced through the job center. The job center will offer services such as; job seekers’ profile creation and inclusion in the online Labour Market Information System (LMIS) database, counselling/career guidance, occupation profiling, job search, job matching, job advertisement (on notice boards and online), job interview space and employers’ platform, internet access, secretarial bureau and an online employability improvement training (package). Through this program, the project expects increased and easy connection of youth with jobs and business opportunities. Additionally, the project will evolve the technical skills trainings from plain learning to learning coupled with production by supporting youth internships and apprenticeships with private sector companies. The project will engage with private sector companies in the target value chains to facilitate an on-site training approach at farm fields and processing centres. This approach combines skills acquisition, production techniques and market orientation and allows youth to apply skills learned, builds knowledge and confidence, and often opens future employment possibilities. In turn it helps to increase a company’s technological know-how, taps into young people’s drive and ambition, and creates a new work ethic. Additionally, the project will evolve the technical skills trainings beyond learning to learning with production through supporting youth internships and apprenticeships with private sector companies. The project will engage with private sector companies in the target value chains to facilitate an on-site training approach at farm fields and processing centres within the normal business. This approach combines skills acquisition, production techniques and market orientation and allows youth to apply skills learned, builds knowledge and confidence, and often opens future employment possibilities. In turn it helps to increase a company’s technological know-how, taps into young people’s drive and ambition, and creates a new work ethic.

title.narrative: OP Ind 2.2.1a: # of skilled youth wage employed

description.narrative: This indicate counts the number of wage employed youth on an annual basis through annual survey

comment.narrative: None of the youth enrolled for skilling was employed by any agribusiness at the time of enrollment.

This indicator had be targeted to come into effect in the last quarter of the year to give youth about 3 months after completion of the skilling cycle to find work but will be reported in second quarter because all the 16 youth skilled by Asiima Agri-Concern were retained as employees
114 (25F/89M) youth are wage employed after completing the skilling cycle in Poultry, Apiculture, Dairy, Crop and animal extension services, juice processing.

title.narrative: OP Ind 2.2.1.b: # of skilled youth graduates retained by agribusinesses

description.narrative: This indicator tracks the number of youth skilled by agribusinesses and retained as employees

comment.narrative: The targets for this indicator will be determined after MoUs have been signed with the agribusinesses and agreed number of youth to be retained indicated.

93 (26F/67M) youth were retained by the 6 Agribusiness include; 34 (4F/30M) youth retained by Asiima, 14 (6F/8M) youth retained by GUCD, 23M youth retained by Jeka Poultry Farm and 22 (16F/6M) retained in the Western by AGDI, CEILO & Macarena Juice Processors.

title.narrative: OP Ind 2.2.1c: # of agribusinesses that absorbed skilled youth graduates

description.narrative: This indicator captures the number of agribusinesses that retain youth they have trained to become part of their work force

comment.narrative: 6 Agribusiness retained 93 youth i.e. Asiima (34), GUCD (14), Jeka Farm (23), AGDI, CEILO and Macarena Juice processors absorbed (22) youth.

title.narrative: IO 4.3: Evidence-based reforms in agri-skilling and agribusiness management conducted leveraging on action research

description.narrative: The development ecosystem is congested with actors applying different approaches or models to achieve common objectives/goals. It is always a dilemma to choose which of the approaches is most effective unless there is scientifically sound evidence to guide any decisions on which approach or model to use. In the agri-skilling and agribusiness thematic areas such approaches exist and stakeholders face the same challenges when choosing the ones to apply. The SAY project plans to conduct one action research on important aspects and agri-skilling and another one on youth employment in agribusiness. This will provide vital data and information to guide stakeholders across the board when designing and implementing agri-skilling and job creation interventions for youth, a tangible contribution to the agri-skilling and job creation enabling environment.

title.narrative: IO Ind 4.3: % of developed evidence-based ecosystem (agri-skilling, gender, environment and agribusiness) responsive frameworks mainstreamed and applied by stakeholders
IO 4.1: Targeted Government of Uganda Ministries, Departments and Agencies operationalized agri-skilling and job creation policies and systemic reforms

description.narrative: The direct involvement of specific government ministries namely Agriculture (for policy guidance, specialized technical services, linkage of youth to government programs and absorption of skilled youth into extension service schemes), education (for skills development related linkages and support), and gender labour and social development (under which youth and employment issues fall) are required not only for the creation of enabling environment but for the execution of processes and attaining results of project interventions. In order for agri-skilling reforms to yield expected results as indicated in the Technical and Vocational Education and Training policy (2019-2024), the mandated body (Agriculture Sector Skills Council) to lead the reforms must implement the planned reform interventions. SAY project plans to facilitate the ASSC in the implementation of these reform interventions. The ASSC will in turn support the skilling process of the project. The MAAIF is agriculture mother ministry and the project aims to engage MAAIF for agribusiness and extension policy popularization, integration of trained youth into extension service provision, technical service provision in training of plant doctors and linking of project beneficiaries to government programs. The project also plans to engage Ministry of Trade, Industry and Cooperative and specifically Uganda Industrial Research Institute to provide Business Incubation Management Services to the young people and other incubators, UNBS for certification of youth products, URSBS and URA for business formalization of youth led agribusinesses. Achieving the desired outcomes from the targeted interventions with government bodies will directly contribute to a favourable enabling environment for youth engagement in agriculture.

title.narrative: IO Ind 4.1a: % of agri-skilling and job creation reform policies operationalized with support from the project
IO Ind 4.1b: % of supported Government bodies that successfully conducted agri-skilling and job creation policy and systemic reforms
OP 4.3.2: Assessment and Training Packages for level 2 and 3 occupations reviewed and updated or developed to be market-responsive through multi-stakeholder engagement

description.narrative: The dynamic and fluid nature of the world of work in the twenty first century means new dimensions or requirements are added to jobs at regular intervals and job holders or those seeking will need to have the skills to be competently perform in the jobs. For the training centers to contribute to this trend and ensure that entrants into the job market have the demanded soft and technical skills, it is paramount to renew the training delivery model at regular intervals. In the SKY project analysis of wage employment showed that youth employed at occupation levels 2 and 3 earned well above the UGX 300,000/= (€70) mark and experienced a more positive change in socio-economic status that those employed at level 1. For this reason, SAY project will concentrate on skilling youth at level 2 and 3 and for these ATPs need to be reviewed or developed for use in the project and nationally. This process will require the involvement of public and private sector actors as well as youth so that the final product is acceptable by all and readily adopted for skills development. This will go a long way to reform skilling and contribute to the enabling environment.

title.narrative: OP Ind 4.3.2a: # of ATPs reviewed/developed and approved for national use
OP Ind 4.3.2b: # of Agri-skilling centers that adopted and operationalized approved ATPs
OP 1.1.2: Youth have their job competencies assessed and certified.

description.narrative: The market demands competent employees that add value to productivity. At enrollment orientation sessions will be conducted for the registered youth to enlighten and prepare them on facts in the world of work, opportunities in agribusiness sectors with specific focus on key selected value chains at regional and national level. The youth will also be briefed on the DIT Competence based assessment, its importance and their payment of assessment fee. Skills providers who are not accredited by DIT will be supported to get accreditation to enable them become DIT assessment centers. The skilled youth will be assessed and certified by the Directorate of Industrial Training (DIT) which is the quality assurance body mandated to carry out competence based assessment and provide certification of the assessed competent youth.

title.narrative: OP Ind 1.1.2a: # of youth assessed by DIT

comment.narrative: At the start of the project none of the youth have neither been skilled nor assessed

dimension.name: OP Ind 1.1.2b: # of youth that passed DIT assessments and certified

comment.narrative: Q1 of 2022 had 207 (67F, 140M) assessed by DIT at level 2 for the occupations they have been skilled for. This is 6% of the 2022 target of 3440 youth to be assessed. This low assessment rate was expected due to the slow completion rate for the skilling and continued difficulty in getting youth assessed by DIT due to confusion round the cutting list that DIT assessor demand. The SAY team have held several meetings with DIT and agreed that moving forward a more flexible approach to availing cutting lists for assessment will be followed.
The target of 1720 is based on the assumption that out of the 1800 youth who will complete their skilling cycles in year 1, 80 will miss the assessment for one reason or the other
Youth assessed: 468 (201F/267M) youth were assessed by DIT in the 4 regions where the SAY project is undergoing implementation.

title.narrative: OP Ind 1.1.2b: # of youth that passed DIT assessments and certified

description.narrative: The youth are assessed for the aim of certification. This indicator tracks youth who are assessed and received certification from DIT

comment.narrative: All the youth assessed in 2021 were able to pass their test and were accordingly certified
The pass rate for the DIT assessment was 83.6% which is more than 5% below the targeted pass rate of 90%. those that were not able to pass will be prepared for reassessment in the next quarter.

title.narrative: OP 4.3.3: Action Research sustainable market-responsive agri-skilling and agribusiness models conducted

description.narrative: The project intends to engage in action research with key public and private sector entities to develop, evaluate, and adopt innovations and models that are relevant to skills development and youth employment. This will ensure efficiency, effectiveness and sustainability of the various models during implementation. Approved innovations and models will further be applied or scaled up to increased access to markets, youth incomes and agribusiness growth. The project plans to conduct 2 action researches on prioritized learning themes across the span of the project. This will add to the body of knowledge available to guide and inform skills development and employment creation for youth in the agriculture sector.

title.narrative: OP Ind 4.3.3a: # of action researches conducted
OP Ind 4.3.3b: # of action research papers published
OP 4.3.1: Gender-responsive and climate-smart agribusiness strategies developed and adopted by all stakeholders for national use

description.narrative: The project intends to facilitate partner agribusinesses to develop and adopt gender sensitive and climate-smart strategies for improved productivity and climate change mitigation and adaptation. Institutions will be engaged through capacity building and mindset interventions aimed at behavioral change and systems strengthening. The project will support institutions to improve/develop strategies, work procedures, training modules and approaches that respond to the main gender related challenges. Female and male youth experience to promote inclusive learning and businesses. On the hand the project will promote the development, adoption and scale up of environmental conservation and business innovations. Focus will be put on use of green energy, waste management, climate smart agriculture, water and soil fertility management.

title.narrative: OP Ind 4.3.1b: # of agribusinesses with at least 40% female employees

comment.narrative: Inorder to improve the equity level of job access to females, the SAY project has dialogued with engaged agribusinesses to have at least 40% of their employees female. It is yet to be seen if they will take action

4 Agribusinesses were able to retain mainly female graduates of the SAY project to work for them as full time employees and this raised the quota of their employees who are female to over 40%. This is a good start given the impact of COVID19 on businesses yet these 4 were still able to employ the graduates of the skilling program.

title.narrative: OP Ind 4.3.1a: # of agribusinesses with gender-responsive strategies/policies

comment.narrative: The plan in 2021 was to have all skills providers to have gender action plans that when operationalized will ensure that female beneficiaries who are pregnant or lactating are catered for at the skilling centers. Some of the proposals in the GAP included baby friendly spaces, designated sanitary facilities (unshared) for males and females.
5 Agribusinesses were able to complete and submit their gender action plans. The rest were scheduled to so the same in the first quarter of 2022.

title.narrative: OP Ind 4.3.1b: # of agribusinesses with climate smart strategies/policies

comment.narrative: The SAY Climate Smart Agriculture team has planned to support at least 5 agribusinesses to develop and operationalize the business CSA strategies proactively.
In 2021, it was not possible to facilitate the agribusinesses to develop and operationalize their climate smart agriculture strategies. This activity has been moved to 2022.

title.narrative: Youth highly skilled and gainfully employed in the agriculture sector in Uganda

description.narrative: The project intends to have an impact on the agri-skills level of youth in Uganda and their gainful employment and this will be contributed to by 4 main high-level outcomes which are the specific objectives of the project. in the SKY project 5,519 youth 18-30 years out of 6,763 (82%) equipped with agripreneurship skills attained gainful employment in the agriculture sector (data from the period progress monitoring report of the project). An additional 4,208 youth 13<18 years in secondary schools acquired agripreneurship skills too. In the new project the intention is to increase the number to 10,000 youth to be skilled for immediate employment and 5,000 youth below 18 years for engagement in agribusiness as career choice path or main economic activity.

title.narrative: The project narrative report for 2021
Overall % of youth 13<30 years highly skilled and gainfully employed in agriculture sector in Uganda

description.narrative: Number of youth skilled by the project in the 13<18 and 18-30 years categories employed in agriculture and earning at least €120/person/month divided by the total enrollment target (15,000)

comment.narrative:
In the first 6 months of the SAY project, AVSI has executed start-up activities aimed at establishing a strong foundations, system, framework and a technical team that will deliver the expected results of the project. As per the Theory of Change of the project, a set of interrelated interventions clustered into themes will have to be executed inorder to trigger the change process and cause-effect sequences that will lead to the desired outcomes of the project. Key programming lessons learnt from the SKY project informed establishment of these thematic areas. Private Sector Development (PSD) was merged with Business Development for form Agribusiness and PSD. Gender Mainstream and Climate Smart Agriculture that were crosscutting areas in SKY were upgraded into core thematic areas because of their importance for the achievement of the SAY results. A new thematic area Agri-financing, Markets and Linkages was introduced to take care of linking the youth to core service points and resources namely financing, markets and job opportunities. Communications is another thematic area that has been inserted into the SAY project with close linkages to MEAL to ensure a more effective communication of results and packaging of various outputs of the project. Skills Development, and Monitoring Evaluation Accountability and Learning (MEAL), are old thematic areas that have remained untouched but improved programmatically.
In the year 2021, the project target of youth gaining employment was 1340 out of 3,200 targeted for skilling. This 1,340 split into 1040 going into agripreneurship (self-employment) and 300 into wage employment within the agriculture sector. Assessment of gainful employment has been set at 6 months after starting a venture or wage employment and the project earning lower limit is set at 120 euros (equivalent to 500,000 UGX). As active skilling commenced in the second quarter of 2021, there were 333 beneficiaries in employment by the end of the year with less than 30% in employment for more than 4 months.

title.narrative: Technical Standards and Strategies developed and approved
