description.narrative: The project thematic specialists developed technical standards and strategies that will be rolled out to all partners and used for skilling and executing all implementation processes of the SAY project.

title.narrative: Number of technical references and strategies developed and approved by the project PMU

description.narrative: The standards and strategies are developed participatorily by thematic themes within the SAY project, inputs sought from contemporaries within the sector, experts peer review the developed materials and the PMU approves final document.

dimension.name: Agribusiness and Private Sector Development Strategy
Monitoring Evaluation Accountability and Learning Strategy
Monitoring Evaluation Accountability and Learning Strategy
Monitoring Evaluation Accountability and Learning Strategy

comment.narrative: The various technical teams in their working groups comprised of AVSI staff and external experts used the lessons learnt from the SKY project, prevail circumstances in the current Ugandan context, emerging trends and best programming practices, and recommendations from the final evaluation of SKY and Tracer Study of SKY graduates to design standard programming procedures (SPPs) of the SAY project in the form of strategies. Each thematic area’s strategy was appraised and peer-reviewed by respected actors before they were adopted by the SAY PMU for utilization in the project. The following strategies/models have been developed and adopted for use in SAY project:  Agribusiness and Private Sector Development Strategy  Skills Development Strategy  Climate Smart Agriculture Strategy  Gender Mainstreaming Strategy  Agri-Financing, Market Systems and Linkages Strategy  MEAL Strategy  Communication Strategy  AVSI’s Earn As You Learn model  Sports for Agripreneurship model  Most Significant Change model The contextual analysis findings provided further grounds to refine the strategies and what is in place right now is well grounded to the Ugandan context, responsive to the conditions and assumptions on the ground and adaptable to all the different regions and agro-ecological zones to enable the achievement of outputs that will lead to the desired change processes and outcomes.

title.narrative: OP 3.1.1: Students trained in agriculture and entrepreneurship skills

description.narrative: The validated Sports for Agribusiness model will be used to transfer knowledge and skills to students in agribusiness club activities. All students in agribusiness clubs will receive life skills training and agriculture training using the standardized training packages. Best farmers and selected entrepreneurs in agribusiness will be engaged to provide career and inspiration talks to students bring on board market experience with regard to successful agripreneurship. The project will link the schools to wide network of agribusinesses and will facilitate learning visits for agribusiness club members.

title.narrative: OP Ind 3.1.1b: # of youth who attained at least 70% post-test score in agripreneurship assessment

description.narrative: This is an indicator for an activity conducted at the end of the school year, thus reported annually

title.narrative: OP Ind 3.1.1a: # of youth who attended capacity development activities (S4A, Life skills training)
IO 2.1: Skilled youth employed in agripreneurships

description.narrative: This intermediate outcome is important as it segregates income earned by you and enable the determination to what extent employment in agribusiness contributes to overall income of skilled youth for it to be considered the primary ‘breadwinner’.

title.narrative: IO Ind 2.1: % of skilled youth 18-30 years self-employed in agribusiness

description.narrative: This indicator determines the total number of youth who go into agripreneurship out of the total number that have been skilled

comment.narrative: This baseline will be determined after the enrollment of the first cohort of youth. For now a figure of x is

title.narrative: OP 3.2.1: youth in rehabilitation centers trained in agripreneurship skills

description.narrative: This outcome is focused on the extent to which the youth offenders in rehabilitation are supported by the project to acquire soft and entrepreneurial skills through specific and tailored training. Life skills training is an integral part of the skilling program to support them to improve their resilience to social and economic aspects. All the strategies will be developed involving the respective matrons of the remand home since the initial stages of the implementation. At the same time, social workers of the remand homes will be involved to ensure the sustainability of the program as well as the parents of the children in rehabilitation to guarantee them constant support also when they return home.

title.narrative: OP Ind 3.2.1a: # of youth in rehabilitation centers trained in agripreneurship skills

comment.narrative: 155(3F/152M) juveniles where skilled at Naguru Remand Home in 3 value chains enterprises namely; Mushroom, Rabbitry and Horticulture. Important to note that there are very few girls at the juvenile remand centers. Therefore the number of boy will continue to be very high and that of girls very low.

In Q1, 80 juvenile were enrolled and killed in agripreneurship and Naguru Remand Home. The remand home is on track to meet the 2022 target of 300 as the skilling is also set to start in Gulu and Kabale remand homes.

title.narrative: OP Ind 3.2.1b: # of Rehabilitation centers facilitated to skill youth

description.narrative: This indicator captures the Rehabilitation centers engaged to skill youth. This will be tracked in the first and second years of the project

comment.narrative: So far Naguru Remand Home skilling beneficiaries between 13-17 years in Agripreneurship.
The Remand Homes of Naguru, Gulu and Kabale have all been engaged for skilling of juveniles in agripreneurship in 2022.

title.narrative: IO 2.2: Skilled youth showed competitive edge for agribusiness jobs

description.narrative: This outcome is focused on the extent to which the youth skilled and supported by the project compete against youth who were not project beneficiaries.

title.narrative: IO Ind 2.2: % of skilled youth 18-30 years in wage-employed

comment.narrative: Enrolment data will be used to determine the baseline and will be adjusted annually until enrolment target is achieved.

title.narrative: IO 3.2: Rehabilitated youth chose agriculture as a safe alternative livelihood

description.narrative:
This outcome is proposed for children in rehabilitation providing them with basic agripreneurship skills that can help them to start own enterprises after being released. At the same time, the focus will be in changing their mindset so that through agriculture they can better reintegrate themselves into their community. The community will be also more likely to accept them as they become productive and active members of the society. The period children take in remand homes is variable and so specific and tailored strategy will be adopted in order to cover as broad as possible all the soft and agribusiness entrepreneurial skills. This will equip them with adequate capacity to into simple self-employment. Those who will stay for a period above 3 months can consider to undertake short courses and being assessed by DIT. In this way, together with a new mindset and basic agripreneurship skills, they will be able to acquire a valid certificate which will help them once they reintegrate themselves into their community. The cost for undertake the DIT assessment will be entirely covered by the project considering the vulnerability of these youth category. This is a new outcome area that was not implemented directly in SKY
The project targets to reach 1,000 youth 13<18 years children under rehabilitation. Decision will be made on which Rehabilitation centers to engage after assessment and discussions with the Ministry of Gender Labour and Social Development.

title.narrative: IO Ind 3.2: % of rehabilitated youth 13<18 years engaged in agribusiness as a safer livelihoods option
Intermediate Outcome (IO) 1.1: Skilled youth demonstrated competence and job-readiness for agribusiness occupations

description.narrative: Youth in the SKY project were able to find employment simply because they had the DIT certificates that clearly indicated their competencies and that aided the decision-making of potential employers to hire them. Assessing and certifying the competence level of youth graduates also guides them and their potential employers on their best fit slots in jobs. AVSI proposes to continue with the certification of the youth on a cost-shared basis with the youth meeting part of the assessment and certification costs. Without doubt, the DIT certificates are tangible to the youth graduates. This outcome is dependent on skilled and certified youth engaging in occupations in agribusiness and excelling. Under SKY youth were skilled in different occupations in agriculture value chain across the four sub regions. The tracer study done indicates that the skilled youth were not earning adequate income from agribusiness due to inadequate skills attained. In the new project youth with be provided with both technical and soft skills through working with public private sector. It is crucial to work with the private sector because it is the highest employer. Different strategies will be employed to ensure that the youth get updated hands on skills and the competence of skilled youth will be assessed by DIT

title.narrative: IO Ind 1.1a: % of skilled youth 18-30 years assessed by DIT.
IO Ind 1.1b: % of assessed youth 18-30 years certified by DIT
OP 4.2.2: Youth agripreneurs accessed markets, investment capital and other critical agribusiness services through established private sector-led trade and investment platforms

description.narrative: Youth will be able to access markets, investment capital and other critical agribusiness services for improved productivity. This will be made possible through the establishment of agri-skilling and agribusiness multi-stakeholder platforms aimed at strengthening public private partnerships for financial inclusion, business development, market access, regulation and enforcement, supplies and technology. In addition, establishing platforms for market system strengthening and linkages between agribusinesses and youth agripreneurs. Capital investment and self-financing model focusing on VSLA and EAYL models. Furthermore, an agribusiness challenge fund will be established where best youth agripreneurs will be rewarded with start-up/scale up funds. Strategic linkages will also be established for youth business capital funding.

title.narrative: OP Indicator 4.2.2a: # of agripreneurs who accessed markets through established linkages/platforms

description.narrative: This indicator tracks the number of project beneficiaries who access markets to sell their products or purchase inputs through platforms established by the project.

comment.narrative: No target was set for this indicator because there was uncertainty about the possibility of establishing market platforms in the middle of the COVID19 pandemic. The project was on standby to incase the conditions became favourable for market activities.
No platform was established in 2021 so this indicated wasn't measurable.

title.narrative: OP Indicator 4.2.2b: # of agripreneurs who accessed investment capital through established linkages/platforms

comment.narrative:
In Q1, 30 agripreneurs of the project were able to access bank loans through linkages that was established between their groups and the financial institutions. This was in Bidibidi Refugee Settlement.
In the rest of the project areas, at least 150 youth have applied for financial credit but have not yet received feedback.

The SAY project piloted the Agribusiness Challenge Fund in which 5 best candidates received agribusiness inputs of their choosing worth an average of UGX6 million shillings to invest in their on-going ventures. This was a pilot that will be scaled up in 2022

title.narrative: OP Indicator 4.2.2c: # of agripreneurs who accessed critical services (e.g. business incubation, product certification) through established platforms/linkages
